metadata.section_summary:
### Summary:

This section from the N-BEATS paper, published at ICLR 2020, discusses various parameters and configurations used in the N-BEATS model, specifically focusing on the ensemble building, model sharing, lookback period, batch size, and detailed parameters for both the interpretable (N-BEATS-I) and generic (N-BEATS-G) models.

**Key Topics and Entities:**

1. **Loss Functions and Ensemble Building:**
   - Different loss functions are used to build ensembles.
   - Mixing models trained on various metrics improved performance for M4 and M3 datasets.
   - For the TOURISM dataset, training only on MAPE yielded the best validation scores.

2. **Coefficient Sharing:**
   - Interpretable model performs best with shared weights across stacks.
   - Generic model performs best with no shared weights.

3. **Lookback Period:**
   - Defined as the length of the history window forming the input to the model.
   - Dependent on the forecast horizon length (H).
   - Models with lookback periods of 2H, 3H, 4H, 5H, 6H, and 7H were mixed in one ensemble.

4. **Batch Size:**
   - A batch size of 1024 was used.
   - Larger batch sizes sped up training, but gains were minimal beyond 1024.

5. **N-BEATS-I Parameters:**
   - **S-width:** Width of fully connected layers in the seasonality stack.
   - **S-blocks:** Number of blocks in the seasonality stack.
   - **S-block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the seasonality stack.
   - **T-width:** Width of fully connected layers in the trend stack.
   - **T-degree:** Degree of polynomial in the trend stack.
   - **T-blocks:** Number of blocks in the trend stack.
   - **T-block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the trend stack.

6. **N-BEATS-G Parameters:**
   - **Width:** Width of fully connected layers in the generic model's blocks.
   - **Blocks:** Number of blocks in the generic model's stack.
   - **Block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the generic model's stack.

These parameters and configurations are crucial for understanding the architecture and training process of the N-BEATS model.

__data__.text:
Published as a conference paper at ICLR 2020
Losses is the set of loss functions that is used to build ensemble. We observed on the respective
validation sets that for M4 and M3 mixing models trained on a variety of metrics resulted in
performance gain. In the case of TOURISM dataset training only on MAPE led to the best validation
scores.
Sharing deﬁnes whether the coefﬁcients in the fully-connected layers are shared. We observed that
the interpretable model works best when weights are shared across stack, while generic model works
best when none of the weights are shared.
Lookback period is the length of the history window forming the input to the model (please refer to
Figure 1). This is the function of the forecast horizon length, H. In our experiments we mixed models
with lookback periods 2H,3H,4H,5H,6H,7Hin one ensemble. As an example, for a forecast
horizon length H=8and a lookback period 7H, the model’s input will consist of the history window
of 7·8=56 samples.
Batch is the batch size. We used batch size of 1024. We observed that the training was faster with
larger batch sizes, however in our setup little gain was observed with batch sizes beyond 1024.
D.2 N-BEATS-I PARAMETERS
S-width is the width of the fully connected layers in the blocks comprising the seasonality stack of
the interpretable model (please refer to Figure 1).
S-blocks is the number of blocks comprising the seasonality stack of the interpretable model (please
refer to Figure 1).
S-block-layers is the number of fully-connected layers comprising one block in the seasonality
stack of the interpretable model (preceding the ﬁnal fully-connected projection layers forming the
backcast/forecast fork, please refer to Figure 1).
T-width is the width of the fully connected layers in the blocks comprising the trend stack of the
interpretable model (please refer to Figure 1).
T-degree is the degree pof polynomial in the trend stack of the interpretable model (please refer to
equation (2)).
T-blocks is the number of blocks comprising the trend stack of the interpretable model (please refer
to Figure 1).
T-block-layers is the number of fully-connected layers comprising one block in the trend stack
of the interpretable model (preceding the ﬁnal fully-connected projection layers forming the back-
cast/forecast fork, please refer to Figure 1).
D.3 N-BEATS-G PARAMETERS
Width is the width of the fully connected layers in the blocks comprising the stacks of the generic
model (please refer to Figure 1).
Blocks is the number of blocks comprising the stack of the generic model (please refer to Figure 1).
Block-layers is the number of fully-connected layers comprising one block in the stack of the generic
model (preceding the ﬁnal fully-connected projection layers forming the backcast/forecast fork,
please refer to Figure 1).
27

metadata.section_summary:
Summary:
The section discusses the comparison between the generic model forecast (FORECAST-G) and the interpretable model forecast (FORECAST-I) in the context of time series forecasting. It explains how the outputs of different stacks within these models contribute to the overall forecast. Specifically, it highlights that the outputs of Stack 1 and Stack 2 in the generic model sum up to form FORECAST-G, while the outputs of the Trend and Seasonality stacks in the interpretable model sum up to form FORECAST-I. Despite differences in individual stack outputs, the combined forecasts (FORECAST-I and FORECAST-G) are shown to be very similar. The section also includes detailed numeric traces of signals visualized in a referenced figure (Fig. 2) and provides tables (Tables 19–24) to demonstrate the numeric values of each signal, ensuring that the names of signals in figure legends and table columns match for easy cross-referencing.

__data__.text:
(ACTUAL), the generic model forecast (FORECAST-G) and the interpretable model
forecast (FORECAST-I). Columns (b) and (c) show the outputs of stacks 1 and 2 of the generic model,
respectively; FORECAST-G is their summation. Columns (d) and (e) show the output of the Trend
and the Seasonality stacks of the interpretable model, respectively; FORECAST-I is their summation.
E D ETAILED SIGNAL TRACES OF INTERPRETABLE INPUTS PRESENTED IN
FIGURE 2
The goal of this section is to show the detailed traces (numeric values) of signals visualized in Fig. 2.
This is to demonstrate that even though the StackT-I (Fig. 2 (d)) and StackS-I (Fig. 2 (e)) provide
response lines different from the counterparts in Stack1-G (Fig. 2 (b)) and Stack2-G (Fig. 2 (c)), the
summations in the combined line (Fig. 2 (a)) can still be very similar.
First, we reproduce Fig. 5 for the convenience of the reader. Second, for each row in the ﬁgure, we

### Summary:

The section introduces the N-BEATS (Neural Basis Expansion Analysis for Time Series Forecasting) model, a deep learning architecture designed for univariate time series point forecasting. Key topics and entities include:

1. **Authors and Affiliations**:
   - Boris N. Oreshkin, Dmitri Carpov, Nicolas Chapados (Element AI)
   - Yoshua Bengio (Mila)

2. **Abstract**:
   - The N-BEATS model uses backward and forward residual links and a deep stack of fully-connected layers.
   - It is interpretable, versatile across various domains, and fast to train.
   - Tested on datasets like M3, M4, and TOURISM, it shows state-of-the-art performance, improving forecast accuracy significantly over benchmarks and previous competition winners.
   - The model's performance on diverse datasets suggests that deep learning primitives alone can solve a wide range of forecasting problems.
   - The architecture can be augmented for interpretability without losing accuracy.

3. **Introduction**:
   - Time series forecasting is crucial for business applications, impacting areas like inventory control, customer management, and business planning.
   - Despite the success of deep learning in fields like computer vision and NLP, it has struggled to outperform classical statistical methods in time series forecasting.
   - The M4 competition results highlighted the dominance of classical statistical techniques and hybrid models over pure ML methods.
   - The winning model of the M4 competition was a hybrid of neural networks and classical statistical models.
   - This work challenges the notion that hybrid approaches are necessary, exploring the potential of pure deep learning architectures for time series forecasting.
   - The authors aim to design an interpretable deep learning architecture that can achieve high forecasting accuracy.

### Key Topics:
- N-BEATS model
- Time series forecasting
- Deep learning vs. classical statistical methods
- Interpretability in deep learning
- Performance on M3, M4, and TOURISM datasets

### Key Entities:
- Authors: Boris N. Oreshkin, Dmitri Carpov, Nicolas Chapados, Yoshua Bengio
- Organizations: Element AI, Mila
- Datasets: M3, M4, TOURISM
- Competitions: M4 competition
- Models: N-BEATS, Holt-Winters model, hybrid neural network-statistical models

The section sets the stage for discussing the N-BEATS model's architecture, performance, and implications for the field of time series forecasting.

### Summary:

The section describes the architecture of a proposed neural network model for time series forecasting, presented as a conference paper at ICLR 2020. The key components and concepts include:

1. **Basic Building Block**: The fundamental unit is a multi-layer fully connected (FC) network with ReLU nonlinearities. This block predicts basis expansion coefficients for both forward (forecast) and backward (backcast) directions.

2. **Stack Organization**: Blocks are organized into stacks using a doubly residual stacking principle, allowing for the construction of a deep neural network with interpretable outputs. Each stack can have layers with shared parameters for forward and backward predictions.

3. **Input and Output**: The model input is a lookback window, and the output is a forecast period. The input window is typically a multiple of the forecast horizon \( H \), ranging from \( 2H \) to \( 7H \).

4. **Block Operations**: Each block has two outputs: a forward forecast (\( \hat{y}_\ell \)) and a backcast (\( \hat{x}_\ell \)). The block consists of two parts:
   - **Fully Connected Network**: Produces forward (\( \theta_f \)) and backward (\( \theta_b \)) expansion coefficients.
   - **Basis Layers**: Use these coefficients to generate the backcast and forecast outputs.

5. **Equations**: The section provides equations describing the operations within a block, including the transformation of inputs through FC layers and the linear projection to obtain expansion coefficients. The basis layers then map these coefficients to the final outputs.

### Key Entities:
- **ICLR 2020**: The conference where the paper was published.
- **FC Stack**: Fully connected layers with ReLU nonlinearities.
- **Forecast and Backcast**: Forward and backward predictions.
- **Stack Residual**: Mechanism for passing residuals to the next stack.
- **Lookback Window**: Model input.
- **Forecast Period**: Model output.
- **Horizon \( H \)**: Forecast horizon.
- **Expansion Coefficients (\( \theta_f \), \( \theta_b \))**: Parameters predicted by the network.
- **Basis Layers (\( g_f \), \( g_b \))**: Layers that project expansion coefficients to outputs.
- **Equations**: Mathematical representation of the block operations.

This architecture aims to optimize forecasting accuracy by effectively utilizing basis functions and residual connections.

### Summary:

The section discusses the architecture and interpretability of the N-BEATS model, a neural network for time series forecasting. Key topics and entities include:

1. **Forecast and Backcast Basis Vectors**: The section introduces the concepts of forecast (vf) and backcast (vb) basis vectors, and their respective expansion coefficients (θf and θb). These vectors can be either learnable or set to specific functional forms to incorporate problem-specific inductive biases.

2. **Doubly Residual Stacking**: The section proposes a novel hierarchical doubly residual topology. This architecture has two residual branches: one for backcast prediction and another for the forecast branch. The structure facilitates gradient backpropagation and hierarchical decomposition of forecasts, making the network more interpretable.

3. **Interpretability**: Two configurations of the architecture are proposed:
   - **Generic Deep Learning (DL)**: This configuration does not rely on time series-specific knowledge and uses linear projections for gb and gf.
   - **Interpretable Configuration**: This configuration incorporates inductive biases to enhance interpretability.

4. **Equations and Operations**: The section provides equations describing the operations of the doubly residual stacking architecture, emphasizing the hierarchical aggregation of partial forecasts.

5. **Matrix Interpretations**: The section explains the interpretation of matrices Vf and Vb in the context of the model, where Vf represents waveforms in the time domain and θf are the expansion coefficients.

Overall, the section focuses on the architectural innovations and interpretability aspects of the N-BEATS model, highlighting its hierarchical and residual stacking features.

### Summary:

The section discusses the architecture and components of the N-BEATS model, focusing on trend and seasonality modeling, and the use of ensembling for improved performance.

**Key Topics and Entities:**

1. **Trend Model:**
   - **Monotonic or Slowly Varying Function:** The trend is typically a monotonic or slowly varying function.
   - **Polynomial Constraint:** The trend is modeled using a polynomial of small degree \( p \) to mimic this behavior.
   - **Forecasting Equation:** \( \hat{y}_{s,\ell} = \sum_{i=0}^{p} \theta_{f_{s,\ell,i}} t^i \)
   - **Time Vector \( t \):** Defined on a discrete grid for forecasting \( H \) steps ahead.
   - **Matrix Form:** \( \hat{y}_{tr_{s,\ell}} = T \theta_{f_{s,\ell}} \)

2. **Seasonality Model:**
   - **Periodic Function:** Seasonality is modeled as a regular, cyclical fluctuation.
   - **Fourier Series:** Used to model periodic functions.
   - **Forecasting Equation:** \( \hat{y}_{s,\ell} = \sum_{i=0}^{\lfloor H/2 - 1 \rfloor} \theta_{f_{s,\ell,i}} \cos(2\pi it) + \theta_{f_{s,\ell,i+\lfloor H/2 \rfloor}} \sin(2\pi it) \)
   - **Matrix Form:** \( \hat{y}_{seas_{s,\ell}} = S \theta_{f_{s,\ell}} \)

3. **Interpretable Architecture:**
   - **Two Stacks:** Trend stack followed by seasonality stack.
   - **Doubly Residual Stacking:** Removes trend component before feeding into the seasonality stack.
   - **Separate Outputs:** Provides separate interpretable outputs for trend and seasonality.
   - **Residual Connections:** Stacks consist of several blocks connected with residual connections.
   - **Shared Weights:** Sharing weights across blocks in a stack improves validation performance.

4. **Ensembling:**
   - **Importance in M4-Competition:** Used by top entries for better performance.
   - **Diversity:** Core property of an ensemble; achieved by fitting models on different metrics (sMAPE, MASE, MAPE).
   - **Training on Different Input Windows:** For every horizon \( H \), models are trained on input windows of different lengths.

The section emphasizes the structured approach to modeling trend and seasonality and the effectiveness of ensembling in enhancing model performance.

### Summary:

The section discusses the implementation, training, and interpretability of the N-BEATS model, a neural network for time series forecasting, as presented in a conference paper at ICLR 2020.

#### Key Topics:
1. **Implementation and Training**:
   - N-BEATS is implemented in TensorFlow.
   - Parameters are shared across different forecasting horizons, allowing one model per horizon for each dataset.
   - The architecture and hyperparameters (e.g., width, number of layers, number of stacks) are consistent across horizons and datasets.
   - Training involves sampling batches of 1024 time series (TS) IDs and using the Adam optimizer with an initial learning rate of 0.001.
   - Early stopping is employed, and training duration varies between 30 minutes to 2 hours depending on settings and hardware.

2. **Generalization**:
   - The architecture generalizes well across different types of time series, as evidenced by successful training on diverse datasets like the M4 Monthly and M3 Others subsets.

3. **Interpretability**:
   - The model can be made interpretable by constraining certain components to polynomial and Fourier basis forms.
   - The interpretable configuration decomposes forecasts into trend and seasonality components, with distinct properties for each.
   - The trend output is monotonic and slowly moving, while the seasonality output is regular and cyclical.
   - The magnitude of these outputs varies based on the presence of trend or seasonality in the time series.

#### Key Entities:
- **N-BEATS Model**: A neural network architecture for time series forecasting.
- **TensorFlow**: The framework used for implementing and training the model.
- **Adam Optimizer**: The optimization algorithm used during training.
- **M4 and M3 Datasets**: Benchmark datasets used to evaluate the model's performance.
- **sMAPE Metric**: A metric used for optimizing ensemble members.
- **Polynomial and Fourier Basis**: Mathematical forms used to make the model interpretable.

The section concludes that the N-BEATS model can achieve both high performance and interpretability by incorporating sensible inductive biases into its architecture.

The section primarily discusses various ablation studies conducted on the N-BEATS model to evaluate its performance using the sMAPE metric. The key topics and entities covered include:

1. **Layer Stacking and Basis Synergy**:
   - **Layer Stacking**: The study investigates the impact of increasing the number of stacks in the generic architecture, each consisting of one residual block with 5 fully connected (FC) layers. Results in Table 5 show that increasing the number of stacks reduces the error, with diminishing returns after a certain point.
   - **Basis Synergy**: The interpretable architecture, which combines trend and seasonality models in different stacks, shows improved performance when layers are stacked. Table 6 indicates that architectures with different basis functions (trend and seasonality) perform better than those with a single type of layer.

2. **Ensemble Size**:
   - Figure 3 demonstrates that increasing the ensemble size enhances performance. N-BEATS achieves state-of-the-art performance with a relatively small ensemble size of 18 models, indicating computational efficiency.

3. **Doubly Residual Stacking (DRESS)**:
   - The section describes the DRESS principle, which involves running a residual backcast connection and producing partial block-level forecasts aggregated at stack and model levels. The study compares the accuracy of this topology against alternatives by removing either the backcast or partial forecast links or both, while keeping the number of parameters constant.

### Key Entities:
- **sMAPE (Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error)**: The performance metric used for evaluation.

- **Interpretable Architecture**: Combines trend and seasonality models in different stacks.
- **DRESS (Doubly Residual Stacking)**: A topological principle used in N-BEATS.
- **Residual Block**: A component of the network architecture.
- **Fully Connected (FC) Layers**: Layers used within residual blocks.

### Summary:

The section discusses the performance and architectural variations of the N-BEATS model, particularly focusing on its application to the M4 dataset. Key topics include:

1. **Ensemble Size and Performance**: Figure 3 illustrates that N-BEATS maintains high performance (less than 0.5% loss in OWA) even with a significantly smaller ensemble size.

2. **Architectural Variations**:
   - **N-BEATS-DRESS**: The default configuration using doubly residual stacking.
   - **PARALLEL**: Disables backward residual connections, with each block forecasting in parallel.
   - **NO-RESIDUAL**: Disables backward residual connections, with each block's output feeding into the next.
   - **LAST-FORWARD**: Uses backward residual connections but only the last block's forecast is used.
   - **NO-RESIDUAL-LAST-FORWARD**: Disables both backward residual and partial forward connections, resembling a deep feed-forward network.

3. **Quantitative Ablation Study**: Results from Tables 7–10 show that the doubly residual stacking topology (N-BEATS-DRESS) outperforms other architectures. The study used an ensemble size of 18 for N-BEATS-DRESS, compared to 180 for N-BEATS-G, aligning with the performance trends shown in Figure 3.

4. **Overall Advantage**: The doubly residual stacking topology provides a clear advantage over other configurations, as evidenced by the results on the M4 dataset.

### Summary:

This section from the N-BEATS paper, published at ICLR 2020, discusses various parameters and configurations used in the N-BEATS model, specifically focusing on the ensemble building, model sharing, lookback period, batch size, and detailed parameters for both the interpretable (N-BEATS-I) and generic (N-BEATS-G) models.

**Key Topics and Entities:**

1. **Loss Functions and Ensemble Building:**
   - Different loss functions are used to build ensembles.
   - Mixing models trained on various metrics improved performance for M4 and M3 datasets.
   - For the TOURISM dataset, training only on MAPE yielded the best validation scores.

2. **Coefficient Sharing:**
   - Interpretable model performs best with shared weights across stacks.
   - Generic model performs best with no shared weights.

3. **Lookback Period:**
   - Defined as the length of the history window forming the input to the model.
   - Dependent on the forecast horizon length (H).
   - Models with lookback periods of 2H, 3H, 4H, 5H, 6H, and 7H were mixed in one ensemble.

4. **Batch Size:**
   - A batch size of 1024 was used.
   - Larger batch sizes sped up training, but gains were minimal beyond 1024.

5. **N-BEATS-I Parameters:**
   - **S-width:** Width of fully connected layers in the seasonality stack.
   - **S-blocks:** Number of blocks in the seasonality stack.
   - **S-block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the seasonality stack.
   - **T-width:** Width of fully connected layers in the trend stack.
   - **T-degree:** Degree of polynomial in the trend stack.
   - **T-blocks:** Number of blocks in the trend stack.
   - **T-block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the trend stack.

6. **N-BEATS-G Parameters:**
   - **Width:** Width of fully connected layers in the generic model's blocks.
   - **Blocks:** Number of blocks in the generic model's stack.
   - **Block-layers:** Number of fully connected layers per block in the generic model's stack.

These parameters and configurations are crucial for understanding the architecture and training process of the N-BEATS model.
